comments.author: inthecornfields79

comments.text:
When I see this clip, I am reminded of how I wish my father had been that 
honorable man.  But, sadly, he was not.  But his son tries and that is all 
one can ask.﻿
comments.author: Ronald Marks

comments.text:
+Ronald Marks Me too. I always cry when I watch this film, and wish my 
father was like Atticus, but he is not. My father was an alcoholic that 
beat my mother, my brother and me.

I did never forgave him, neither did he ever felt ashamed or said ''I am 
sorry son, I was not so good as a father.''

That unresolved trauma from the childhood will follow me to the rest of my 
life. 

And maybe that is the reason why characters like Atticus were my real 
childhood role models. John Wayne, Gregory Peck, Errol Flynn, Gary 
Cooper... were my film fathers, and ''black and white'' naive idealistic 
representation of good and wrong of golden days of Hollywood was my real 
ethical and moral influence.
comments.author: Sam Packinpah was a classical composer

comments.text:
Wow, Ron, I feel so fortunate because in so many ways my dad ~was~ Atticus 
Finch - at least to my sister and me. I was lucky to be his son and this 
scene more than any other reminds me of him. I cry whenever I see it. :-)

comments.author: Elisabeth Zguta

comments.text:
I never fail to cry my eyes out when I watch this, means so much to me 
personally, as a victim of discrimination, and should do to all humankind 
as Atticus is so excellently human and recognises unlike southern society 
(at this time) the equality and humanity of the african-americans and this 
scene is the great moment of the film as it shows that this respect and 
appreciation is, of course, mutual. I often think that Atticus is an 
exemplar of a Hero for the modern age, wielding the unstoppable forces of 
Truth and Love. This is why this is so sad as the evil of racism has 
(temporarily) stopped these, and why his bravery is so admirable as he 
knows even with an incontrovertible case that he will not succeed. ﻿

comments.text: they stand up for him because he stood up for them.
comments.author: Squirrel Knight

comments.text:
Not only was Dill based on Harper Lee's real childhood friend and neighbor, 
Truman Capote, but there has always been a persistent rumor that Capote 
actually did most (or even all) of the writing of "To Kill a Mockingbird". 
It is a tantalizing rumor made all the more believable because Harper 
Lee... after writing one of the great novels of our time... never had 
anything published again. Still, I choose to believe that Ms. Lee is the 
sole author and that facts seem to back that up.
comments.author: Ken Graham

comments.text:
The best part of the wonderful piece of moviemaking is Jem. If you remember 
the beginning of the movie... and especially in the book... he is always 
complaining that his dad is so "old" and that his friends fathers are so 
much more fun. However as the movie progresses, culminating with this 
scene, he comes to realize that not only is his father better than all his 
friends' fathers combined, but he is darn near a superhero.
comments.author: Ken Graham

comments.text:
He was found guilty despite overwhelming evidence that he was innocent. He 
was then shot when he tried to escape from jail. :(

comments.text:
O God.. I just saw this play yesterday in Denver! Just so amazing .. Must 
say I cried to the point of embarrassment. The play was so well done.. 
Atticus was a dead ringer for Gregory Peck. I love this scene. More wisdom 
in this play than just about anything I have ever seen. Wouldn't it be fun 
to go to Harper Lee's hometown in Alabama for the annual production they do 
of the play there? In April. I'm serious! Let's go!
